topics.title: Introduction and Background
topics.summary: Cold open highlights Hilary’s philosophy on product leadership and resilience, followed by Lenny’s intro of Hilary’s background and why she’s a standout guest.

topics.title: Sponsor Break
topics.summary: Ads for WorkOS (enterprise auth/SCIM/authorization) and Persona (identity verification and fraud prevention).

topics.title: Why resilience matters more than ever
topics.summary: Hilary explains why she focuses on helping teams “take a punch,” tying it to hard product domains, AI-driven uncertainty, layoffs, and the need for managers to lead through fear.

topics.title: Counter-programming after you take a punch
topics.summary: Hilary shares a concrete tactic: stop litigating perceptions and instead take a small next action that demonstrates the opposite of the feared narrative, illustrated with her ketamine-tracking meeting example.

topics.title: CBT behavioral activation applied to management
topics.summary: Drawing from her work at Big Health, Hilary connects “take a punch” to CBT behavioral activation: act first to break negative spirals, then feelings improve—using small, reliable actions.

topics.title: Second-order benefits: confidence to speak up
topics.summary: Hilary explains how resilience skills reduce fear of embarrassment, helping people contribute in meetings, earn their seat, and accelerate career growth—rather than staying silent to avoid risk.

topics.title: Hot take: too many PMs play easy mode
topics.summary: Hilary argues many product builders choose comfortable, prestigious problems and wishes more would apply craft to harder, higher-stakes domains like low-income services and social impact work.

topics.title: Transparency: teaching how leaders think
topics.summary: Hilary describes sharing weekly context from key meetings—what was said, her interpretation, and resulting actions—to help teams build accurate mental models and reduce approval bottlenecks.

topics.title: When you disagree with leadership decisions
topics.summary: Hilary outlines how to represent decisions you don’t fully agree with: seek the missing insight, separate your opinion from their rationale, and align the team around execution to learn what’s true.

topics.title: Magic questions: statements ending in “agree?”
topics.summary: Hilary shares a technique for extracting someone’s mental model: propose a concrete statement or option and ask “Is that right?” to quickly learn what they accept/reject, avoiding vague open-ended loops.
